headline: Obasanjo carpets secession agitators, describes disintegration calls as ‘idiotic’
summarized_story:
FORMER President Olusegun Obasanjo has called on all agitators who promote disintegration of the country to shelve the idea and work for the unity and oneness of the country.
According to Obasanjo, it is better for all ethnic groups in Nigeria to remain together.
The former president advised that it was better for Nigeria to remain as one indivisible nation than for each tribe to go its separate ways.
Obasanjo spoke at the luncheon and investiture of Kehinde Isijola as the new Chairman of Nigerian Institution of Surveyor, Ogun State chapter at the premises of the Olusegun Obasanjo Presidential Library, Abeokuta.
He said although the present situation in the country was not palatable, calling for the disintegration of the country was not the solution.

headline: I’m not surprised by my husband’s death, TB Joshua’s widow declares
summarized_story:

This according to the Minister of Information and Culture, Lai Mohammed is part of the move to regulate the social media platforms.
“What we are saying is that all platforms, you must register in Nigeria.
“Whether it is Netflix, Iroko, or Facebook…they are all doing business in Nigeria, making money and they are not paying taxes.
With its suspension, Nigeria joins countries like China, Turkey, and Myanmar that have all moved to restrict access at some time to Twitter and other Western social media.

headline: Judiciary Workers Suspend Strike, After More Than Two Months
summarized_story:
The Judiciary Staff Union of Nigeria (JUSUN) has suspended its industrial action after over two months.
The union had embarked on the strike on April 6, shutting down all courts nationwide, to demand financial autonomy for the judiciary in states.
JUSUN’s suspension of the strike followed a meeting of its national executive council (NEC) held in Abuja on Wednesday.
Abiri that the union’s other grievances include; non-payment of peculiar allowance for judiciary staff; the attempt by the Kaduna State Governor to place the State judiciary under its civil service and scheming for a State Judicial Council.
He, therefore, requested that the Accountant-General of the Federation be directed to deduct from source the amount meant for the Judiciary before the Union could call off the strike.

headline: Continue Using Twitter – NASS Joint Minority Caucus Urges Nigerians
summarized_story:
The Joint Minority Caucus of the Senate and the House of Representatives has met over the ban on Twitter by the All Progressives Congress (APC)-led Federal Government and has restated its condemnation of the embargo as draconian and unacceptable.
This position was contained in a communique signed by Senator Enyinnaya Abaribe the Minority Leader of the Senate) and Hon.
In the statement, the Joint Minority Caucus also dismissed threats by the APC-led government to arrest and prosecute Nigerians using Twitter and calls on Nigerians to go ahead and use their Twitter as they would not be contravening any law in Nigeria or any international statute.
The joint caucus, therefore, called on Nigerians to use various opportunities offered by technology and continue making use of Twitter since such does not violate any law in our country.
“It is agonizing that Nigeria and Nigerians have been losing billions of naira on daily basis since the ban on Twitter.

headline: Three Soldiers Injured As Troops Kill ISWAP Terrorists In Borno
summarized_story:
Troops of the Nigerian Army under the Operation Hadin Kai have killed several ISWAP Terrorists in Dikwa town, Borno State.
They were, however, met with superior fire power by troops in conjunction with air bombardment by Air Task Force.

headline: Gunmen raid Ekiti community, kidnap 4
summarized_story:
Gunmen on Tuesday night invaded a popular hotel in Ayetoro-Ekiti in Ido\Osi local government area of Ekiti state and reportedly kidnapped four persons.
It was gathered the attackers, numbering 30 on motorcycles, invaded the hotel in a commando-like manner around 9:30pm.
A community source said the bandits came into the community through Ewu-Ekiti, a neighbouring town.
He explained they shot sporadically and shot a staff of the hotel in the arm and kidnapped three others.

headline: Police arrest IPOB/ESN native doctor in Imo
summarized_story:
The Tactical teams of the Imo state Police Command has arrested a notorious native doctor who prepares charms for members of the proscribed Indigenous people of Biafra and eight others.
The suspect confessed to be a member of IPOB/ESN, and made useful statements to the Police as regards to the recent attacks on Police stations as well as the residence of Governor Hope Uzodinma.
However, two (2) out of the nine arrested in the hideout, CHINEDU NWAKAIRE aka ONE DOOR and UZOAMAKA UGOANYANWU (their native Doctor) were identified to be part of the hoodlums that attacked the private residence of Gov.
Hope Uzodinma and also some Police stations as well.

headline: NECO Will Not Extend Registration For 2021 SSCE Internal Candidates – Sani
summarized_story:
The Head of Information and Public Relations Division,Azeez Sani, has revealed that the National Examinations Council (NECO) will not extend the registration period for internal candidates for the 2021 Senior School Certificate Examination (SSCE).
Mr. Sani stated in a statement on Wednesday that the registration period, which began on March 31st, will end on Friday, June 25th, 2021, and will not be extended.
According to him, this will enable efficient and effective planning for the examination logistics required for the smooth conduct of the 2021 SSCE internal candidates.
“State Ministries of Education, Commandants, Principals, Proprietors, and other relevant stakeholders are enjoined to take note of the closing date and ensure timely completion of their candidates’ registration.
Advertisement“The Council assures all stakeholders of its resolve to have seamless conduct of the 2021 SSCE”, he further stated.

headline: US to Share 500 Million Covid Vaccines Through COVAX for Africa, Others
summarized_story:
The US will buy 500 million more doses of the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine to share through the global COVAX alliance for donation to 92 lower income countries and the African Union over the next year, a person familiar with the matter said Wednesday.
Two hundred million doses — enough to fully protect 100 million people — would be shared this year, with the balance to be donated in the first half of 2022, the person said.
The U.S. has faced mounting pressure to outline its global vaccine sharing plan.
Overall, the White House has announced plans to share 80 million doses globally by the end of June, most through COVAX.
Sullivan said Wednesday that he does not expect the U.S. push to waive the patents on vaccines to cause tension with European counterparts.

headline: Twitter, Other ICT Players Contributed 14.91% to Nigeria’s GDP, Civil Society Group Reminds FG
summarized_story:
A leading civil society organization, Centre for Social Justice (CSJ) has reminded the federal government that Twitter and other social media platforms belong to the Information Communications sector which contributed 14.9 per cent to the 2021 first quarter (Q1) gross domestic product (GDP).
CSJ, which expressed regret over the recent ban on the micro-blogging site by the federal government called for an immediate reversal of the action.
“The Information and Communications sector is composed of the four activities of Telecommunications and Information Services; Publishing; Motion Picture, Sound Recording and Music Production; and Broadcasting.
It observed that the fact that Nigeria is just struggling to exit recession even compounds the scenario.
It noted that the ban on Twitter at a time of great economic and social crisis has so many downsides without any evident upside.

headline: Nigeria: I’d Rather Die Than Pay Ransom to Kidnappers, Says Kaduna Governor El-Rufai’s Wife
summarized_story:
One of the wives of Governor Nasir El-Rufai of Kaduna state, Hajiya Asia El-Rufai, has declared that she would rather die than ransom be paid to kidnappers if she gets abducted.
She said she was ready to die in the hands of kidnappers if it will bring peace to the country.
“For as long as you continue to pay ransom, it is like you are adding kerosene to fire.
“We should not pay ransom.
According to her, as long as the bandits are paid ransom, they will not change.

headline: US Drops Trump Order Targeting TikTok, Plans Its Own Review
summarized_story:
Officials are particularly concerned about apps that collect users’ personal data or have connections to Chinese military or intelligence activities.
The Biden administration last week expanded a Trump-era list of Chinese companies that Americans can’t invest in because of purported links to the Chinese military and surveillance.
Last year, the Trump administration brokered a deal that would have had U.S. corporations Oracle and Walmart take a large stake in the Chinese-owned app on national security grounds.
The U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has put on hold a case challenging Trump’s TikTok divestment order.

headline: Nigeria: Judicial Workers Suspend Two-month Long Strike
summarized_story:
The Judiciary Staff Union of Nigeria (JUSUN) has called off its two-month long strike with effect from 14th June, 2021 after a prolonged National Eexecutive Council (NEC) meeting.
The National Judicial Council (NJC) had, at a meeting on Tuesday with JUSUN leaders and the Chief Justice of Nigeria (CJN), Justice Ibrahim Muhammad, urged the striking court workers to put an end to the industrial action in the interest of the country and the suffering court users.
Members of the union have been on strike since April 6, 2021 in agitation for the financial independence of the various state judiciaries.
A subsequent Executive Order was issued by the Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari for the “Implementation of financial Autonomy of States Legislature and State Judiciary” on 20th May 2020.
However, some state governors have failed to implement this fundamental provision of the Law.
